Wensi Wu
  • about me (current)
  • cv
  • publications

I am a PhD candidate at Cornell University. I enjoy developing and applying computational methods to address important research questions in science and engineering. In my doctoral studies, I undertook a project that focuses on the computational modeling of slamming phenomena. (this work can have a profound impact on future ship hull design for preventing ship incidences.) In particular, I first developed a computational "microscope" for the study of a complex multiphysics phenomenon, hydrodynamic slamming. Subsequently, I verified and validated the computational solver against numerical benchamarks and experimental results to ensure the veracity of simulation results. Upon the arrival of a trusted software, I captitalized on computer simulations and deduced a novel engineering theory that charaterizes slamming impact forces resulting from oblique slamming impact.

In the course of my PhD, I gained invaluable experience in software development, computational analysis, and theory formulation for fluid, structural, and FSI applications. Moving forward, I would like to transfer my knowledge in continuum mechanics and computational modeling to a more human-focused discipline -- computational biomedical engineering. I hope to build and/or leverage an accurate and physics-based computational tool to help push the progress in the field of pathology, as an important step towards precise medicine.
news
Apr 26, 2021

Successfully defended my Ph.D. dissertation!

Apr 02, 2021

The article A Principled Approach to Design Using High Fidelity Fluid-Structure Interaction Simulations is published in Finite Elements in Analysis & Design!

Apr 22, 2020

The article CU-BENs: A structural modeling finite element library is published in SoftwareX.

Apr 19, 2020

Released a new version of CU-BENs. CU-BENs is an open source structural finite element analysis software developed by members in Prof. Earls research group.

Jul 28, 2019

Presented at the 15th U.S. National Congress on Computational Mechanics.

Presentation title: Tightly Coupled, Partitioned Fluid-Structure Interaction Analysis of a Flat Plate Slamming onto a Water Free Surface: Computational Framework and Validation.

May 15, 2019

A video produced with my fellow Structural Engineering Ph.D. students took second place in the CEE Video Contest organized by the Cornell CEE GSA.

Jul 09, 2018

Presented at the 13th World Congress on Computational Mechanics.

Presentation title: Implicit Partitioned Fluid-Structure Interaction Modeling Framework for Naval Applications: The Impact of Slamming Loads on High Speed Watercrafts.

Jun 07, 2018

A co-authered conference paper Interface Reduction on Hurty/Craig-Bampton Substructures with Frictionless Contact is published.

Jul 19, 2017

Presented at the 14th U.S. National Congress on Computational Mechanics.

Presentation title: Partitioned Fluid-Structure Interaction for the Study of Wave Impact Loads on High Speed Watercrafts.
